bibl.title: Letter from H. Carter Redd to Philip Showalter Hench, March 5, 1948

div1.p: Redd informs Hench that he will be sending the trunks, containing the Carter correspondence, shortly.

div1.head: Letter from H. Carter Redd to Philip Showalter Hench, March 5, 1948
div1.opener:
Commissioner of Accounts and Commissioner in
Chancery of Circuit Court of Hanover County
H. CARTER REDD
ATTORNEY-AT-LAW
1104 TRAVELERS BUILDING
RICHMOND, VA.
March 5th, 1948
Dr. P. S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I have gotten the trunks of papers from storage and
the only opportunity I have to look them over is at night
when I get back home from my office in Richmond; my home
being in Ashland, twenty miles distant.

I frequently have clients who live in Ashland and
find it more convenient to consult me at night than to
come to Richmond, and because of this I am delayed in
completing the sorting and packing of the papers; the
sorting and packing consisting of simply arranging them
in compact form and packing them in the trunks. I think
I can get the contents of the three trunks into two small
ones.

I am not reading the letters because it would take
too long and I am sending them to you just as they are
without having arranged anything in sequence; I just do
not have the time to do that.

I do find a good deal of stuff which would be of
no interest to you and it would be useless to pay the
express on it; for instance, last night I ran across a
letter book full of correspondence between Dr. Carter,
his daughter and myself in regard to financial business
matters, which, of course, would be of no use to you. I
also found a lot of pictures in frames of people I do
not know and doubt if anyone would know, other than Dr.
Carter of Birmingham. I will send the trunks on to you
as soon as I can possibly do so.

You will find publications and in some instances
several copies of the same publication. There will be no
objection to your keeping one of each where there are
more than one, when you wish to do so.
